original_title: Sri Lanka President to be sworn in, four member cabinet
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s President-elect Anura Dissanayake would be sworn in on September 2024 and a four member cabinet will be appointed, National People’s Power party officials said.
The Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna, the driving force behind the National People’s Power of now has three members in parliament.
The resignation of Dissanayake would create a vacancy which will be filled with a new member, legislator Harini Amarasuriya said.
The parliament would be dissolved in about a week, an NPP official said. The new government is expected to have at least 15 ministries.

“I have always believed that the only government that can take the country out of the crisis should have a mandate from the people,” Dissanayake said Sunday after being declared the winner by the island’s independent Elections Commission.
Sri Lanka’s challenges cannot be solved by a single party he said.

“My expectation is to treat as sri Lankans without any division all those who placed their trust in me and take the country forward,” Dissanayake said Sunday after being declared the winner by the island’s independent Elections Commission.

The NPP came to power of strong anti-corruption platform. They also pledged to reduce the threshold on personal income tax, with direct taxes becoming the key point of contention in the IMF program after the currency collapsed under ‘monetary policy modernization’.
More direct taxes are planned by the IMF in the form of taxing housing as a form of wealth tax.
The opposition Samagi Jana Balawegaya has critized the plan and also wanted to reduce income tax on wage earners, before the election.
President Wickremesinghe also presented a plan to reduce personal income tax, which came on top of currency depreciation by the central bank which pushed up inflation to 70 percent in 2022.
Sri Lanka’s NPP to push IMF anti-graft moves, negotiate path to other targets: econ council chief
The NPP also had some concerns about the imputed taxes they would discuss with the IMF, the head of the NPP’s economic council Anil Jayantha said.
